title: 113_hr3074
content: The "IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013" requires notice for accessing account, return, or return information. The IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013 mandates that the Secretary must notify taxpayers in writing whenever their account, return, or return information is accessed, with special rules for investigations. The IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013 requires the Secretary to notify taxpayers in writing when their account, return, or return information is accessed for investigations. The notice must include details on who accessed the information, the purpose of access, and how it was accessed. The IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013 mandates the Secretary to provide written notice to taxpayers when their information is accessed for investigations. The notice includes a copy of the accessed information and details on subsequent use, along with taxpayer rights information. Additionally, the availability of Inspector General for Tax Administration reports is ensured. The IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013 requires the Secretary to notify taxpayers if their information is accessed for investigations. The Inspector General for Tax Administration must inform the taxpayer of any investigation and provide access to related reports. State access to taxpayer information is subject to notification to the Secretary. The IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013 mandates reporting unauthorized access of taxpayer information to the Secretary and relevant committees. The Inspector General for Tax Administration must also report any violations or unauthorized access to Congress. The IRS Abuse Protection Act of 2013 requires reporting unauthorized access of taxpayer information to the Secretary and relevant committees. The effective dates for the amendments made by subsections (a) to (d) apply to information accessed, investigations closed, access and disclosures, and reports prepared after the date of enactment of the Act.
